verses.text: Now there was a man in Caesarea named Cornelius, a centurion of what was called the Italian Regiment.
verses.comment: Cornelius is introduced as a Roman centurion, highlighting the spread of the Gospel beyond Jewish boundaries.

verses.text: He was a devout man, who feared God with all his household, gave alms generously to the people, and prayed to God always.
verses.comment: Cornelius, though a Gentile, practices acts of mercy and prayer, showing God's grace extends to all who earnestly seek Him (see Ps. 145:18).

verses.text: About the ninth hour of the day, he saw clearly in a vision an angel of God coming to him, and saying to him, 'Cornelius!'
verses.comment: The ninth hour was a traditional hour of prayer (see Acts 3:1); God's initiative in sending an angel reveals divine favor and guidance even outside Israel.

verses.text: And fixing his eyes on him, and being afraid, he said, 'What is it, Lord?' And he said to him, 'Your prayers and your alms have come up as a memorial before God.'
verses.comment: Sacrificial prayer and charity please God; the phrase ‘memorial before God’ carries an Old Testament sense of a pleasing offering (see Lev. 2:2).

verses.text: 'Now send men to Joppa, and summon a man named Simon, who is called Peter.'
verses.comment: Cornelius is directed to Peter, indicating the apostolic ministry as the means through which God brings the fullness of truth and sacramental grace.

verses.text: 'He is lodging with Simon, a tanner, whose house is by the sea.'
verses.comment: Specific directions underscore God's providence and the importance of obedience to divine instruction.

verses.text: When the angel who spoke to him had departed, he called two of his household servants and a devout soldier from among those who waited on him continually.
verses.comment: Cornelius immediately obeys, showing faith by action. He involves both his household and those under his authority.

verses.text: After explaining everything to them, he sent them to Joppa.
verses.comment: Delegation shows trust; Cornelius relies on community and cooperation, mirroring Christian fellowship.

verses.text: The next day, as they were journeying and nearing the city, Peter went up on the housetop to pray about the sixth hour.
verses.comment: Peter’s prayer at the sixth hour reflects Jewish custom; continued dedication to prayer marks the rhythm of Christian life.

verses.text: He became hungry and wanted to eat, but while they were preparing, he fell into a trance.
verses.comment: Peter’s hunger and trance link physical need with spiritual revelation, recalling prophetic visions (see Num. 24:4; Ezek. 8:3).

verses.text: He saw heaven opened, and an object like a great sheet descending, let down by its four corners to the earth.
verses.comment: Heaven opening signifies God initiating a new phase in salvation history, much like the vision of Jacob's ladder.

verses.text: Inside it were all kinds of four-footed animals of the earth, wild beasts, creeping things, and birds of the air.
verses.comment: The animals reflect ritual distinctions from the Mosaic law, which God is preparing to transcend for a higher purpose.

verses.text: And a voice came to him: 'Rise, Peter; kill and eat.'
verses.comment: God’s direct command challenges old boundaries, pointing to the coming universality of the New Covenant.

verses.text: But Peter said, 'Not so, Lord; for I have never eaten anything common or unclean.'
verses.comment: Peter’s protest reveals his faithfulness but also the radical newness of what God is doing in Christ.

verses.text: Again, a voice spoke to him a second time, 'What God has made clean, you must not call common.'
verses.comment: God is the one who purifies and sets apart; this signals a deeper mystery concerning the inclusion of the Gentiles.

verses.text: This happened three times, and the object was taken up into heaven at once.
verses.comment: The repetition echoes other significant events that happen in threes to Peter (e.g., John 21:17), marking this as a divine confirmation.

verses.text: Now while Peter was inwardly perplexed as to what the vision could mean, behold, the men sent by Cornelius had made inquiry for Simon's house, and stood at the gate.
verses.comment: God’s timing is perfect; the vision is immediately followed by the arrival of Cornelius’s men, providentially connecting events.

verses.text: They called out and asked whether Simon, who was called Peter, was lodging there.
verses.comment: The details echo the seriousness and careful observance of God’s directions by Cornelius’s household.

verses.text: While Peter was still thinking about the vision, the Spirit said to him, 'Behold, three men are seeking you.'
verses.comment: The Spirit personally guides Peter, underscoring the close relationship between the apostle and the divine.

verses.text: 'Rise therefore, go down and accompany them without hesitation, for I have sent them.'
verses.comment: Peter is commanded to obey even before understanding, trusting the authority and guidance of the Spirit.

verses.text: Peter went down to the men and said, 'I am the one you are looking for. What is the reason you have come?'
verses.comment: Peter’s humility and readiness reminds us of the apostolic responsibility to serve and respond to God’s calling.

verses.text: They said, 'Cornelius, a centurion, an upright and God-fearing man, who is well spoken of by the whole Jewish nation, was directed by a holy angel to send for you to come to his house, and to hear what you have to say.'
verses.comment: Cornelius’s reputation, even among Jews, shows the attractiveness of holiness. Apostolic teaching is to be received as divinely appointed.

verses.text: So Peter invited them in and gave them lodging. The next day he rose and went away with them, and some of the brothers from Joppa went with him.
verses.comment: Peter’s hospitality shows openness to Gentiles. Shared journey hints at the suffice of Christian unity and fellowship.

verses.text: On the following day they entered Caesarea. Cornelius was expecting them and had called together his relatives and close friends.
verses.comment: Cornelius’s expectation and bringing together of family and friends reveal a communal approach to receiving the Gospel.

verses.text: As Peter entered, Cornelius met him and fell down at his feet and worshiped him.
verses.comment: Cornelius’s deep reverence reflects the awe with which the apostolic office was regarded in the Early Church.

verses.text: But Peter lifted him up, saying, 'Stand up; I myself am also a man.'
verses.comment: While honoring the dignity of the apostolic calling, Peter also upholds humility and the unique worship owed only to God.

verses.text: As he talked with him, he went in and found many gathered together.
verses.comment: The Gospel is received within the context of community—an important aspect of Christian life.

verses.text: He said to them, 'You yourselves know how unlawful it is for a Jew to associate with or visit a foreigner; but God has shown me that I should not call any person common or unclean.'
verses.comment: Peter recognizes God’s wider plan—salvation is not limited by nationality or past legal distinctions.

verses.text: So when I was sent for, I came without objection. I ask then, why did you send for me?'
verses.comment: Peter’s ready obedience to God’s call is a model for Christian mission and discernment.

verses.text: And Cornelius said, 'Four days ago, about this hour, I was praying in my house at the ninth hour, and behold, a man stood before me in bright clothing.'
verses.comment: Bright clothing signifies the angelic or heavenly messenger, paralleling Resurrection accounts.

verses.text: And he said, 'Cornelius, your prayer has been heard and your alms are remembered before God.'
verses.comment: Again, the value of intercession and charity before God is affirmed; God’s memory is described in personal terms.

verses.text: 'Send therefore to Joppa and ask for Simon, who is called Peter. He is lodging in the house of Simon, a tanner, by the sea.'
verses.comment: Repetition emphasizes the importance of Peter’s unique role as an apostolic messenger.

verses.text: So I sent for you at once, and you have been kind enough to come. Now therefore we are all here in the presence of God, to hear all that you have been commanded by the Lord.'
verses.comment: The willingness to receive apostolic teaching is essential for faith and for communion with God.

verses.text: So Peter opened his mouth and said, 'Truly, I understand that God shows no partiality.'
verses.comment: The impartiality of God is emphasized, reinforcing the universality of salvation.

verses.text: 'But in every nation, anyone who fears Him and does what is right is acceptable to Him.'
verses.comment: This hints at the fulfillment of the Abrahamic promise—faith and righteousness are what matter in God’s sight.

verses.text: As for the word he sent to the sons of Israel, proclaiming good news of peace through Jesus Christ—He is Lord of all—
verses.comment: Jesus is identified as Lord of all, the fulfillment of messianic prophecy and universal Savior.

verses.text: You yourselves know what happened throughout all Judea, beginning from Galilee after the baptism which John proclaimed:
verses.comment: Peter roots the Good News in history and connects it to John the Baptist’s preparatory ministry.

verses.text: how God anointed Jesus of Nazareth with the Holy Spirit and with power, and he went about doing good and healing all who were oppressed by the devil, for God was with him.
verses.comment: Christ’s anointing fulfills Isa. 61:1; Jesus’s ministry is presented as a divine mission with supernatural authority.

verses.text: We are witnesses of all that he did both in the country of the Jews and in Jerusalem. They put him to death by hanging him on a tree.
verses.comment: 'Hanging on a tree' is a reference to crucifixion and the curse in Deut. 21:23, fulfilled and transformed by Christ.

verses.text: But God raised him up on the third day and allowed him to be seen,
verses.comment: Christ’s resurrection is central; Peter stresses both divine initiative and the reality of eyewitnesses.

verses.text: not to all the people, but to us who were chosen by God as witnesses, who ate and drank with him after he rose from the dead.
verses.comment: Resurrected Christ shares a meal, confirming the physical reality and truth of the resurrection, witnessed by the apostles.

verses.text: And he commanded us to preach to the people and to testify that he is the one appointed by God to be judge of the living and the dead.
verses.comment: Jesus, appointed judge, returns us to Old Testament prophecies of the final judgment.

verses.text: To him all the prophets bear witness that everyone who believes in him receives forgiveness of sins through his name.'
verses.comment: Fulfillment of prophecy is stressed; faith in Christ brings forgiveness—a key message realized sacramentally.

verses.text: While Peter was still speaking these words, the Holy Spirit fell on all who heard the message.
verses.comment: The Spirit descends without hands, revealing Divine sovereignty; but later, the Church will regularize this gift through visible means.

verses.text: And the believers who had come with Peter were amazed, because the gift of the Holy Spirit had been poured out even on the Gentiles.
verses.comment: God acts ahead of human expectations, confirming the universality of the Church.

verses.text: For they were hearing them speaking in other tongues and magnifying God. Then Peter declared,
verses.comment: The charismatic signs repeat those of Pentecost, demonstrating continuity and the fullness of the Spirit’s work.

verses.text: 'Can anyone withhold water for baptizing these people, who have received the Holy Spirit just as we have?'
verses.comment: Reception of the Spirit anticipates but does not supplant baptism. Peter proclaims the necessity of the Church’s sacraments.

verses.text: And he commanded them to be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ. Then they asked him to remain for some days.
verses.comment: Baptism follows faith and the reception of the Spirit, and is administered with apostolic authority. The staying on shows a period of catechesis and instruction in the faith.
